content.title: Momenya, an authentic izakaya

introduction.small: Izakayas are a must for whoever wants to discover Japanese cuisine. In Tokyo, Momenya takes the concept further, drawing direct inspiration from the island's culinary traditions.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Momenya, an authentic izakaya

paragraphs.text:
At the end of a working day in Tokyo, all hands are on deck in izakaya restaurants. These taverns are akin European brasseries: there, you can try popular dishes paired with local alcohols – to be enjoyed in moderation. They are regular hangouts for salarymen who come to release the pressure. In Shinjuku, Momenya adopts a style familiar in the Kansai region, south of the Island. In the heart of Tokyo, this izakaya boasts a welcoming setting, mostly made of wood. You will take a seat on a zabuton, typical cushion used as a chair around a zataku, a traditional low table. Solitary diners will usually sit at the counter facing the open kitchen, and order a plate of tuna sashimi served with sake, or Japanese spring rolls using organic tofu, homemade yuba (soy curds) and fresh fish from the Toyosu market.

Momenya
1-6-16 Takadanobaba
Union Building B1F
Shinjuku
169-0075 Tokyo

+81 3 3232 1221

Menu: around 3,000 JPY

content.title: Muji Hotel, pared-down sense of aesthetics

introduction.small: In Tokyo, Muji opened a hotel furnished with items from their own brand, perfectly embodying their philosophy: comfort, well-being and relaxation.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Muji Hotel, pared-down sense of aesthetics

paragraphs.text:
World-famous for its attention to design, functionality and quality, Japanese household goods company Muji has opened its first hotel in the home country. Expect 79 rooms, from comfortable alcoves to family suites, spread over four floors. The hotel is located above the huge Muji shop of Ginza's chic neighbourhood, full of luxury shops, famed restaurants, trendy coffee shops and nightclubs. For sheer clarity and transparency, Muji Hotel's pricing remains unchanged throughout the year: whether mid-week, during the weekend or a holiday, high or low season, the client always pays the same for a certain room category.

The Muji Hotel Ginza carries the brand's emblematic sober style very well, with environmental responsibility and waste management as main preoccupations. Proud of the “anti-sumptuous, anti-low range” motto, the hotel reveals a particularly stripped-down aesthetic, using natural materials (wood, clay, stone, cotton…). Behind the clear wood bar of the lobby, walls have thus been covered with stones, more precisely paved stones from the former Tokyo tram lines. A large bookshelf brimming with hundreds of Japan-themed books, as well as two galleries where temporary exhibitions are held several times a year will delight design lovers with an interest in the current trends.

A sweet and simple stay, no less!

Muji Hotel Ginza
6F, 3 Chome−3−5
Ginza
Chuo City
104-0061 Tokyo

+81 3 3538 6101

https://hotel.muji.com/ginza/en/

Rooms: from 14,900 JPY

content.title: Manga Art Hotel, bedtime with a book in hand!

introduction.small: Lovers of Japanese comic books will be comfortably installed in the capsules of the Manga Art Hotel. A library in a hotel, for nights of reading ahead!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Manga Art Hotel, bedtime with a book in hand!

paragraphs.text:
Thematic hotels are aplenty in Tokyo. This one is of particular interest to comic book enthusiasts. Designed for solo travellers, the Manga Art Hotel installed its capsules (tiny bedrooms no larger than the size of the mattress, much more affordable than regular hotel rooms) amidst the bookshelves of its library, full of more than 5,000 manga titles. Many are available in their original Japanese editions, but some are also in English for kanji beginners (kanji being the logographic characters of the Japanese writing system).

Literally curled up in your nest, in either single or double bed, you only need to reach for a book to start it out. Manga Art Hotel offers 35 rooms spread over two floors – one for men and one for women – as well as showers looking like a spacecraft, and obviously free Wi-Fi. In case you feel lost among all these books, the hotel staff can guide you and point to custom selections. It is even possible to leave with a personal favourite under your arm. There you are, ready to read all night, maybe until daybreak when you can access the green balcony to admire the sun rising over Tokyo.

Manga Art Hotel
4F 5F, 1 Chome−14−13 Kanda Nishikicho
Chiyoda City
101-0054 Tokyo

+81 3 3525 8701

https://mangaarthotel.com/index-en.html

Rooms: from 2,940 JPY

content.title: Le Bistrot de l'Oie, French brasserie in the heart of Tokyo

introduction.small: This restaurant brings French gastronomy next to Ginza, with a menu conceived by starred chef Andrée Rosier.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bistrot de l'Oie, French brasserie in the heart of Tokyo

paragraphs.text:
A little piece of France is hiding behind the plants of the Tokyo Square Garden, modern skyscraper covered in green on its top and bottom floors. The bright red front and large picture windows offer a glimpse of this restaurant, looking like a French brasserie, which may be surprising in the Japanese capital. For lunch and dinner, food lovers take a seat on the Bistrot de l'Oie's ribbed leather sofas to better enjoy the speciality: goose, like the French name suggests.

Here, you can taste it in a variety of forms, from confit liver to sautéed foie gras with gingerbread, and roasted liver in bitter orange sauce. However, lovers of French food will also be able to try other famous dishes, such as the traditional cassoulet (sausage and beans), fish stew with tomato and vegetables, and stuffed cabbage à l'ancienne. The restaurant's full name, Les Rosiers - Le Bistrot de l'Oie, also reveals a few flavours from Basque country, native region of chef Andrée Rosier (first woman to ever receive the Best Craftsman of France award for her cooking in 2007). Piquillos with salt cod, Basque-style chicken, chipirons in cuttlefish ink sauce, piperade omelette… To say you have an abundance of choices is an understatement!

Les Rosiers - Le Bistrot de l'Oie
3-1-1 Kyobashi
1F Tokyo Square Garden
Chuo
104-0031 Tokyo

+81 3 5542 1805

http://lesrosiers-bistrot.com/

Menu: from 2,550 JPY

content.title: Koé Hotel, for a conceptual stay

introduction.small: Immerse yourself in modern and stylish Tokyo at this hotel unlike any other. You will only wish your stay was longer.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Koé Hotel, for a conceptual stay

paragraphs.text:
In an industrial wasteland atmosphere, with exposed ducts covering the ceiling, the concept of this hotel is its strong point. Enter a place where each of the three floors fulfils multiple functions. On ground floor, you will find the Koé Lobby with a food corner as well as the Koé Space, where cultural events and DJ sets take place every week. Shop on the next floor, where Japanese ready-to-wear designers will greet you. At the end of the day, climb up to the last floor and discover the bedrooms, arranged with high-end furniture for modern and bright results. The Koé restaurant allows you to have breakfast, lunch and dinner to seat in or take away. Strollers will stop and grab a table simply to enjoy a pastry and a cup of coffee. The guarantee of an uncommon experience!

Koé Hotel
3-7 Udagawachō
Shibuya-ku
150-0042 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 6712 7251

hotelkoe.com ﻿

Rooms: from 24,290 JPY

content.title: Circus Outdoor, when glamour and camping come together as one

introduction.small: At Circus Outdoorm comfort has not been left aside, for a camping break in the heart of nature overlooking Okutama Lake.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Circus Outdoor, when glamour and camping come together as one

paragraphs.text:
Camping in nature is great, but with extra comfort it's even better! Riding the wave of glamping (contraction of the words “glamour” and “camping”), Circus Outdoor has set up its 5-star tents in a secret and magical forest, only a few miles away from Tokyo. These cosy yurt-like accommodations shaped like a bao (the stuffed Chinese brioche) are furnished with a bed, sofa and modern or Victorian decoration depending on the room's theme. Everything is made easy to enjoy nature without the inconvenience of a sleeping bag. Watching the stars while seating around a camp fire has provided such serenity.
A chef even comes at night to cook gastronomical dinners and waits for you in the morning for a bespoke breakfast. If you're looking to recharge your batteries away from the city, choose the “digital detox” option and leave all electronic devices at check-in. Don't worry, you will not have to choose between leaving your camera aside and taking pictures as a professional photographer will capture your stay forever.

Circus Outdoor
290-1 Kawano
Okutama-machi, Nishitama-gun
198-0225 Tokyo

www.circusoutdoor.com

Rooms: from 59,400 JPY

content.title: MORI Building Digital Art Museum

introduction.small: Dedicated to digital art, the MORI Building Digital Art Museum immerses you into interactive universes all more enchanting than the other.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MORI Building Digital Art Museum

paragraphs.text:
A team of museum artists and engineers from the TeamLab Borderless group devised this crazy project: revolutionising the museum gesture and offering an unprecedented interactive adventure that breaks the boundaries of digital creation. Cutting-edge techniques are therefore being used in an approach that is at once experimental and organic. Over more than 10,000 sqm, the museum offers you a new way of coming to terms of art, space and the interaction with the public.
By wandering around and touching the universes on display with your eyes and fingers, you will be able to understand that each creation is alive and adapts to you through a series of high-tech captors. Transitions between the spaces are free, just like your movements, and there is no signage to guide you. You will have to create your own visit, which will incidentally change every time you come to the museum. A few hours will be necessary to roam the 50 different environments, gathered into 5 different sections with distinct thematic natures (mankind, nature, technology etc…). A dream awake!

MORI Building Digital Art Museum: TeamLab Borderless
Odaiba Palette Town
1-3-8 Aomi, Koto-ku
Tokyo 135-0064

+81 (0) 3 6406 3949

https://borderless.teamlab.art/

content.title: Stroll in the Koishikawa Korakuen Gardens

introduction.small: After soaking up the city of Tokyo and its bustling streets, take a deep breath of fresh air at Koishikawa Korakuen Gardens and leave on the right foot.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Stroll in the Koishikawa Korakuen Gardens

paragraphs.text:
Considered one of the most beautiful and oldest gardens in Tokyo, dating back to the 17th century Edo period, Koishikawa Korakuen stretches over seven hectares: the guarantee of a long walk in total tranquillity right in the city centre. Far from the hustle and bustle of the surrounding streets, revitalise yourself in a true green paradise, among ornamental plum trees, maples and wisteria. From small paths, wander along the rivers, filled with lotuses and typically Japanese wooden walkways, and the vast peaceful pond, from which you'll reach the other side by taking the Full Moon Bridge. You can also admire the small rice fields, which are planted in May and harvested in September by primary school children. If you go to Koishikawa Korakuen in February, you will have the chance to attend the Ume Flower Festival, an exquisite occasion.

Koishikawa Korakuen
1-6-6 Koraku
Bunkyo
Tokyo 112-0004

+81 (0)3 3811 3015

teien.tokyo-park.or.jp/en/koishikawa/

content.title: Holy expedition on Mount Fuji

introduction.small: A Japanese national symbol, Mount Fuji is a dream come true with its bewildering mountain.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Holy expedition on Mount Fuji

paragraphs.text:
130 kilometres away from Tokyo, Mount Fuji uses its timeless beauty to increasingly attract more hikers who yearn to conquer it. Japan's highest peak at nearly 3,776 metres, the volcano is revered by all who live in the archipelago and consider it a sacred mountain – this national symbol has also been a UNESCO World Heritage site since 2013.
Although it has not spit fire since 1707, the volcano is nevertheless feared by its most superstitious inhabitants, as it is officially still active. In the summer, some 200,000 climbers enjoy themselves wholeheartedly, climbing its pristine white summit, crowned with a crater about 500 metres in diameter. From above, enjoy a glorious panorama like no other. In winter, head down the slopes by skiing or snowboarding. For the less adventurous, the base of Mount Fuji also offers some memorable hikes in the “Five Lakes” region, filled with magnificent caves and waterfalls.

Mount Fuji
Kitayama Fujinomiya
418-0112 Shizuoka

content.title: Zauo, go fishing for your meal

introduction.small: Zauo, the themed restaurant that offers fishing for what you are going to eat.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Zauo, go fishing for your meal

paragraphs.text:
Enter through the door of this rather unique place. In the middle of the room stands a boat with artificial basins where your next meal awaits you. Climb aboard and have a seat! Upon arrival, you are given a fishing rod and bait. Be patient, as it may take a little while before a fish bites. Once caught, the staff will begin singing a laudatory song in respect for your catch. Of course, you do not know which species you are going to fall upon: sea bream, flounder or mackerel; it's a surprise. Hand over your catch to the servers and choose your preferred preparation: grilled, simmered, in sushi…
If you cannot catch your meal, don't worry. You will just have to use the classic menu, where you can order what you would like from among a large selection, such as cuttlefish tempura, yakisoba with shrimp (sautéed noodles) or a plate of sashimi.

Zauo
3 Chome-2-9 Nishishinjuku
Shinjuku
160-0023 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3343 6622

www.zauo.com

Dinner: from 5,000 JPY (price varies according to fish caught)

content.title: For the love of books at Kanda and Jinbōchō

introduction.small: In the central district of Chiyoda, Tokyo, the Kanda and Jinbōchō neighbourhoods are distinguished by the thousands of books that abound.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: For the love of books at Kanda and Jinbōchō

paragraphs.text:
Many neighbourhoods in Chiyoda are a must. Among them, do not miss Kanda and Jinbōchō, nicknamed 'Book Town'. These districts are full of bookstores, antique dealers and second-hand booksellers and invite you to discover a fascinating cultural suburb, where famous universities and schools rub shoulders.

Between prints and old maps from the Edo period at the Ohya bookstore, and specialised publications of arts and civilizations at the Isseido boutique, the neighbourhoods of Kanda and Jinbōchō will be appreciated by bargain hunters and dreamers. Detective books, magazines, mangas, manuals and novels are piled up in a delicious mess for lovers of literature. Kanda is also home to one of Japan's three biggest festivals, the Kanda Matsuri, which every other year (in odd years) features mikoshis - literally 'divine palanquins', as well as Shinto tanks and priests on horseback for a breathtaking show.

Kanda Jimbocho
Chiyoda-ku
101-0003 Tokyo

content.title: The Den, an extraordinary dining experience

introduction.small: Michelin-starred Den in Tokyo experiments with amazing dishes under chef Zaiyu Hasegawa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Den, an extraordinary dining experience

paragraphs.text:
Here is a friendly restaurant where the search for new flavours is on the agenda. A caring staff installs you into one of the eight seats of the bar, facing the chef in full preparation. In a warm atmosphere, Noriko, one of the waitresses, who is also the wife of the chef, will tell you all about the visually stunning culinary creations of her husband. The menu is reinvented every day, but you can always enjoy the foie gras with Japanese plum, stuffed vegetables with rice and turtle meat, and the dashi soup with tofu and yuzu-a hallmark citrus fruit used in the country's cuisine. Do not miss the restaurant's famous dish: the Den salad, made with 20 ingredients! An inevitable stop for a unique experience.

Den
Architect House Hall JIA
2-3-18 Jingumae
Shibuya Ku
101-0051 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 6455 5433

https://www.jimbochoden.com/en/

Menu: around 15,000 JPY

content.title: Maneki-Neko Cat Worship at Gotokuji Temple

introduction.small: How about going to pray to Maneki-Neko in Tokyo for a year full of luck?

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Maneki-Neko Cat Worship at Gotokuji Temple

paragraphs.text:
The origin of this tradition, celebrated on 29 September and known as 'Maneki-Neko Day', continues to fuel legends. Tama, a thin feline of one of the monks of the temple, is said to have invited Lord Ii Naotaka to join it on Gotokuji's forecourt, thus saving him from lightning that struck the place where he had been standing. The tradition could also have its origins in the suicide of a geisha, who ran a house of tea called The Golden Cat.

In the district of Setagaya, the Gotokuji Buddhist temple is the subject of an omnipresent cult. Indeed, hundreds of statuettes are arranged on the altar dedicated to Maneki-Neko, this benevolent cat who waves with its front paw up as a sign of prosperity. On the altar of Gotokuji, these many statuettes are white, as a symbol of purity, and red, for protection.

Gotokuji Temple
2-24-7 Gotokuji
Setagaya-ku
154-0021 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3426 1437

http://honyaku.j-server.com/LUCSETAGAY/ns/tl.cgi/http://www.city.setagaya.lg.jp/index.html?SLANG=ja&TLANG=en&XMODE=0&XJSID=0

content.title: Hantei, juggling the flavours of kushiague

introduction.small: Built in the early 18th century, this beautiful three-floor wooden building is dedicated to traditional Japanese cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hantei, juggling the flavours of kushiague

paragraphs.text:
Not far from Ueno Park, which houses several museums, including the Tokyo National Museum, the Museum of Art Mori and the Museum of Shitamachi, Hantei, is an institution of traditional Japanese architecture and the culinary arts as well. One is impressed by this narrow wooden house, built on three floors, which was a warehouse in the 18th century. This highly photogenic place is popular with food-lovers. On the first floor, sitting on the floor, sample a dozen varieties of delicious skewers of meat, fish and breaded vegetables (kushiague) accompanied by amazing salad and miso soup. Order until you are sated. The bilingual menu also features very sophisticated fish and meat stews. And the grand finale? Irresistible panna cotta with yuzu.

Hantei Nezu
2-12-15 Nezu
Bunkyō-ku
113-0031 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3828 1440

http://www.hantei.co.jp

Menu: around 2,835 JPY

content.title: Nakameguro: a shopping stroll

introduction.small: In the bohemian neighbourhood of Nakameguro, select boutiques abound on the edges of the Meguro river.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nakameguro: a shopping stroll

paragraphs.text:
Get out your t-shirts, put on your good mood, and get going for a shopping expedition along the Meguro.

First stop, the SML mini-store, a laboratory of ceramic creations, glass dishes, and wooden objects. The Cow Books bookstore has an old-fashioned feel that is hard to resist.

You will find papers and writing accessories in the aisles and a selection of novels from the Beat Generation. For your lunch stop, set your heart on the vegetarian restaurant Mother Esta. In the afternoon, you will come across the unexpected at the Green Bean to Bar chocolate bar, and the chic shop, Brick & Mortar, offering a collection of everyday objects from all over the world that add value to modern life.

SML
AK-1 Bldg. 1F, 1-15-1 Aobadai
Meguro
153-0042 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 6809 0696
www.sm-l.jp

Cow Books
1-14-11 Aobadai
Meguro
153-0042 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 5459 1747
www.cowbooks.jp/english.html

Mother Esta
2 Chome-20-14 Aobadai
Meguro
153-0042 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 5724 5778
www.mother-esta.com

Green Bean to Bar
2-16-11, Meguro
153-0042 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 5728 6420
www.greenchocolate.jp

Brick & Mortar
1-4-4 Nakameguro
153-0042 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 6303 3300
www.brickandmortar.jp

content.title: Nezu Museum: a classic in art

introduction.small: The Nezu Museum shows national treasures from countries neighbouring Japan and has a magnificent traditional Japanese garden.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nezu Museum: a classic in art

paragraphs.text:
The Nezu Museum is known both for a unique collection of national treasures from Korea, China, and Japan and for its garden, laid out magnificently around the building.

Close to 7,000 pieces were brought together in the early 20th century by Kaichiro Nezu, president of the Tobu Railway and a great connoisseur of pre-modern art. His son, Kaichiro Junior, decided to create this foundation upon the death of his father in 1940, to honour his passion and to preserve the quality of the collection. Paintings, calligraphy, sculpture, ceramics, lacquer, wood and bamboo artisanal objects, textiles, armour, and even archaeological specimens make up the collections of this unique museum.

You can complete your visit with a walk in the traditional Japanese garden, which highlights bamboo and maple, with Buddha statues spread out on the moss of the forest undergrowth. The garden offers close to 1,700 square metres to explore it is a veritable ode to plant life in the very centre of the city.

Nezu Museum
6-5-1 Minamiaoyama
Minato
107-0062 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3400 2536

www.nezu-muse.or.jp/en/index.html

content.title: A lovely escape to Izu peninsula

introduction.small: Only two hours away from Tokyo, an escapade to see some greenery and warm up your soul after it has been worn down by the noise of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A lovely escape to Izu peninsula

paragraphs.text:
Climb aboard the Japanese high-speed train, the Shinkansen, to travel towards Izu. For close to two hours, you will go through cities, the countryside, and rice paddies, with Mount Fuji looming above.

Stop in Mishima, to visit the contemporary art complex presented in full nature: the Clematis no Oka Centre has three art museums and a literary museum, restaurants, a café and museums shops. Here you can visit the Izu Photo Museum, inaugurated in 2009 by Hiroshi Sugimoto, and wander in the garden, where sculptures by contemporary artists such as Yayoi Kusama and the Italian Giuliano Vangi reach toward the sky. Last stop, for a pleasant night, reserve a room at the luxury ryokan, Asaba, where you will sleep like a lamb on a double futon. You can also dip into the hot springs, the onsen, where you can bath nude in a private indoor hot spring bath.

Finally, in the evening, in a private salon, dressed in a kimono and sitting on tatami mats, you will taste the savoury Izakaya menu at a low table, in the Japanese style.

Clematis no Oka
347-1 Higashino, Nagaizumi
Sunto District
411-0931 Shizuoka
+81 (0)5 5989 8787

www.clematis-no-oka.co.jp

Ryokan Asaba
3450-1 Shuzenji
Izu Shi
410-2416 Shizuoka
+81 (0)5 5872 7000

www.asaba-ryokan.com/en/

content.title: Hidemi Sugino and Higashiya: two-star patisseries

introduction.small: One is the star of patisserie, Hidemi Sugino, and the other is the expression of Japanese minimalism, known as ‘wabi-sabi', at the Higashiya patisserie.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hidemi Sugino and Higashiya: two-star patisseries

paragraphs.text:
Voted best pastry chef in Asia, Hidemi Sugino has reached a level of excellence in the art of combining incongruous tastes.

After having waited 30 minutes in line (a common practice in Japan), your patience will be rewarded with the sight of rich sweets behind the glass ready to awake your taste buds. Dare to taste the rosemary and apricot tartelette, the Emotion cake with milk chocolate mousse and ginger-infused banana, or the unbelievable cheesecake with basil and mango called ‘Néo'. The other merchant of sweet treats, Higashiya, belongs to the well-regarded designer and chef Shinichiro Ogata. On the first floor of a Ginza building, Higashiya produces tiny sugary mini-marvels with incomparable tastes. Each is just shy of a mouthful, so buy a bunch!

The immaculate white decor is warmed with the soothing colours of the wooden furniture to create a very Zen ambiance that will add to the heightening of your senses.

Hidemi Sugino
3 Chome-6-17 Kyobashi
Yubinbango
104-0031 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 3538 6780
www.facebook.com/kyobashihidemisugino?rf=137534596291340

Pastries from 760 JPY

Higashiya
1 Chome-7-7 Ginza
Chuo
104-0061 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 3538 3230
www.higashiya.com

Pastries from 2,000 JPY

content.title: Tokyo vintage at Pass the Baton, Toll Free and Solakzade

introduction.small: At several boutiques selling things from yesteryear, vintage is the name of the game.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tokyo vintage at Pass the Baton, Toll Free and Solakzade

paragraphs.text:
The idea of Masamichi Toyama, owner of Pass the Baton, was to open a recycling shop of a new kind.

Clients bring objects, clothes, artworks, or fashion accessories that are dear to them, but whose time has come. And he passes them along. Dresses from the 1980s, a collection of vintage porcelain, and unique accessories are all presented in the two shops. Toll Free has created one-of-a-kind offerings by deconstructing and reconstructing from vintage elements.

And finally, just for the eyes, enter Solakzade and discover an incredible collection of eyeglasses and sunglasses, including retro models and selections inspired by Hollywood stars; a jewellery shop is also in the works.

Pass the Baton
4 Chome-12-10 Jingumae
Omotesando Hills West Hall B2F
Shibuya

+81 (0)3 6447 0707
www.pass-the-baton.com

Meguro

+81 (0)3 3715 9278
www.hrm.co.jp/tollfree/

Solakzade
Goro's Building B1F
4-29-4 Jingumae
Shibuya
150 001 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 3478 3345
https://www.solakzade.com/en/about/

content.title: Takahashi Collection & The Container: the Alternative Tokyo

introduction.small: Cutting-edge contemporary art can be seen at the Takahashi Collection or in a shipping container dressed up as an art gallery in Nakameguro.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Takahashi Collection & The Container: the Alternative Tokyo

paragraphs.text:
The Takahashi Collection includes 2,000 works collected since the 1990s by psychiatrist Dr. Ruytaro Takahashi himself. A major contemporary art collector, he opens his collection to the public several times a year via thematic exhibitions (visit the website to know their agenda).

A true curator of young talent, he has promoted the success of world- renowned artists such as Makoto Aida, Takashi Murakami and Akira Yamaguchi. Bross/The Container is the most insane gallery in Tokyo, offering top-notch and wilfully unusual programming since 2011. A hair salon dressed up as an art gallery or a gallery disguised as a hair salon?

This implausible premise seduces more and more artists of the new generation. Recently, the Japanese artist Yuta Hoshi transformed the gallery into a contemporary temple dedicated to prayer and meditation. Inspired by Hindu mythology, the installation mixed different technologies and included video, painting, and sculpture.

Takahashi Collection
Hibiya Mitsui Bldg 1F
1-1-2 Yurakucho Chiyoda-ku
100-0006 Tokyo

www.takahashi-collection.com

Bross/The Container
1-8-30 Kamimeguro
Meguro
153-0051 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3770 7750

www.the-container.com

content.title: Senso-ji Temple: the oldest in Tokyo

introduction.small: The largest temple in the capital spreads its grandeur and sparkling red presence in the commercial streets of Asakusa.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Senso-ji Temple: the oldest in Tokyo

paragraphs.text:
The primary place of worship for Japanese Buddhists, the Senso-ji Temple is an imposing presence in the centre of the Asakusa neighbourhood. When you arrive, you will pass under the large red lantern, then through another gate to finally arrive at the threshold of the temple. Also known as the Asakusa Kannon Temple, it is dedicated to Guanyin, the Goddess of Mercy. The Senso-ji sanctuary includes the Senso-ji Hondo building, the den of the goddess, and a five-story pagoda.

As custom dictates, you will bow before an altar and clap your hands twice then leave an offering in the urn to honour the goddess. Behind the pagoda, you can then try to speak with the carp and fresh-water turtles of the pond.

Senso-ji Temple
2 Chome-3-1 Asakusa
Taito
111-0032 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3842 0181

www.senso-ji.jp

content.title: Aman Resort: the chic, urban design temple

introduction.small: In the Tokyo business area, enter the temple of happiness that is this minimalist hotel from the Aman chain.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Aman Resort: the chic, urban design temple

paragraphs.text:
The Aman name has finally arrived in the Nippon megalopolis with a stunning hotel installed on the 33rd floor of the Otemachi tower. Here the codes of the traditional inn, or ryokan, have been brought to bear through beloved materials such as camphor wood, washi paper, and stone. A fusion of natural elements, beauty, and technology deliver you to the heart of a sacred sanctuary of luxury.

Here you can meditate in serenity in the internal garden, dive into the blue 30 metre long pool with a view, go to the holistic massage centre in the magnificent spa with eight treatment cabins, feel Zen-like peace while practicing yoga, learn about Iaido, the martial art of the samurai, in a private lesson, or simply sleep in one of the 84 rooms with fantastic views of the city.

Aman Resort
The Otemachi Tower
1-5-6 Otemachi
Chiyoda
100-0004 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 5224 3344

www.aman.com/resorts/aman-tokyo/

Rooms: from 91,000 JPY

content.title: D47 Design Travel, Syuro, Cibone, and others

introduction.small: Concept and design stores are multiplying like wildfire in the streets of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: D47 Design Travel, Syuro, Cibone, and others

paragraphs.text:
If you are passionate about decor and design, you will have endless choices, as Japan has an incredibly rich and varied artisanal heritage. Lacquer, pottery, ceramics, textiles, paper, wood, and essences are all featured in artisanal objects that are part of a rigorous selection for Tokyo concept stores.

D47 Design Travel presents a collection of traditional Japanese merchandise, regional specialties, classic tools, and gastronomic ingredients from the four corners of the archipelago. Syuro is a mini-store located in the old city of Otemachi, whose artisans revisit the objects of daily life, such as metal tea and biscuit boxes. Cibone is a café and boutique with Nordic styling that presents a collection of tableware, home design, furniture, and clothing.

Finally, the Claska Gallery & Shop Do presents folkloric works of art, lights, fashion accessories, decor items, and Japanese cooking utensils. A real Ali Baba's cave without the 40 thieves!

D47 Design Travel Store
2 Chome-21-1
Shibuya
150-8510 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 6427 2302

www.hikarie8.com/d47designtravelstore/

Syuro
1 Chome-15-7 Torigoe
Taito
111-0054 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3861 0675

www.syuro.info

Cibone
2-27-25 Minami Aoyama
Orix Minami Aoyama Building 2F
107-0061 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3475 8017

www.cibone.com

Claska Gallery & Shop Do
1-3-18 Chuocho
Meguro
152-0001 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 6434 1663

https://do.claska.com/about/

content.title: Andon Ryokan: the design inn

introduction.small: Hiding behind the glass and metal facade, a modern ‘ryokan', awarded an architectural prize in 2005, offers nights in Japanese style.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Andon Ryokan: the design inn

paragraphs.text:
The name Andon comes from the Japanese word for ‘traditional lantern', since, at dusk, when the ryokan is lit up, its structure resembles this famous lamp. If you would like to live in the traditional Japanese style, Andon Ryokan is for you.

Rooms are miniscule but well equipped; when the futon is unrolled it takes up the entire space of the room and covers the wall-to-wall tatami. Conceived by an architecture professor in 2003, this was the first designer ryokan. Here you can encounter a mix of the modern and traditional. The owner collects antique objects, so the excellent breakfast will be served in vintage dishes.

In the shared bathrooms, you will discover the work of pop artist Mie Ishii, who covered a four-metre long wall with traditional porcelain tiles from Arita (a city on the island of Kyushu) with a modern design. The host will also offer you classes in the art of flower arranging, ikebana, or in tea ceremonies as part of the hotel's aim to explain and illustrate Japanese culture to foreigners.

Andon Ryokan
2-34-10 Nihonzutumi
Taito
111-0021 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3873 8611

www.andon.co.jp

Rooms: from 9,000 JPY

content.title: Andaz Toranomon Hills: luxury, calm, and Zen

introduction.small: The city now has an urban refuge, situated in the foothills of the Toranomon Hills, for modern nomads.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Andaz Toranomon Hills: luxury, calm, and Zen

paragraphs.text:
This is not a simple Hyatt hotel but a real urban retreat. Andaz lives up to its reputation of offering clients a new philosophy of service.

No desk or concierge is visible in the lobby. Taking up the last six floors of a tower in the Toranomon Hills, you will be pleased by the poetic and pure décor, conceived by Tony Chi and Shinichiro Ogata. Inspired by Japanese culture, noble materials adorn the rooms and walls beautifully. Traditional washi paper is used on the dividing walls, while Hokkaido walnut and granite give a magisterial and sensual feeling to this exceptional place.

A 20-metre pool with a view over the Imperial Palace and a 'farm-to-table' restaurant are available, not to mention the bar with a panoramic view of night-time Tokyo leading you straight to seventh heaven.

Andaz Toranomon Hills
1-23-4, Toranomon
Minato
105-0001 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 6830 1212

www.tokyo.andaz.hyatt.com

Rooms: from 73,000 JPY

content.title: The Imperial Palace and Edo-Tokyo Museum: back to the future

introduction.small: Three must-see places take us across time on the track of imperial Tokyo, formerly called Edo, the capital of the East since 1868.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Imperial Palace and Edo-Tokyo Museum: back to the future

paragraphs.text:
The Edo period began in 1600 and lasted for two and a half centuries until the Togugawa shogunate capitulated to the Meiji-era emperor. It is this span of history that you will encounter when visiting the Imperial Palace and its gardens.

The palace, previously called the ‘Edo Castle' is still today the principal residence of the Emperor and Empress, and is generally closed to the public. Other than on 23 December and 2 January, you can only admire the outside of the palace, the ramparts, the moats, and the famous Soto Sakuradamon Gate from the alleys of black pines that border the edifice. You can stroll among the Eastern gardens, accessible through the Kitanomaru Park, a real Garden of Eden among the skyscrapers of Marunouchi.

To know more about the life of the shoguns, head to the Edo-Tokyo museum which, in spite of the Le Corbusier-style modern structure, marvellously explains the wonderful history of the city.

Imperial Palace and Kitanomaru Park
1-1 Chiyoda
100-8111 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 3213 1111
http://sankan.kunaicho.go.jp/english/index.html

Edo-Tokyo Museum
1 Chome-4-1 Yokoami
Sumida
130-0015 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 3626 9974
www.edo-tokyo-museum.or.jp/en/

content.title: The Tokyo Station Hotel: sleeping above the Shinkansen

introduction.small: A majestic building in red brick, the Tokyo Station Hotel, located in the main train station, is a symbol of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Tokyo Station Hotel: sleeping above the Shinkansen

paragraphs.text:
The hotel has been operating since 1915 just one year after the train station was inaugurated. In 1964, the Shinkansen, the Japanese high-speed train, appeared and, in 2012, the hotel reopened after six years of renovations.

High-vaulted ceilings are impressive and the large windows offer views of life in the train station, with rooms looking out on the famous dome that photographers have immortalised thousands of times. This hotel, with a contemporary air and European décor, also has small houses, measuring 70 sqm, to keep you in a preserve of calm and far from the madding crowds.

In the atrium, you can enjoy a filling breakfast, then prepare to board the train with your overstuffed trunk.

Tokyo Station Hotel
1 Chome-9-1 Marunouchi
Chiyoda
100-000 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 5220 1111

https://www.thetokyostationhotel.jp/en

Rooms: from 30,339 JPY

content.title: Thermae-yu Spa: the largest onsen in Tokyo

introduction.small: The largest spa in the city opened in 2015 in the business district of Shinjuku, to the delight of Tokyo residents.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Thermae-yu Spa: the largest onsen in Tokyo

paragraphs.text:
Hot springs and baths (onsen) have an important role in the life of the Japanese. More than just recreation, they are indicative of a way of life, with water being one of the key elements of their culture.

A large, six-story spa allowing an escape from the urban jungle makes sense here in its very centre, in a Shinjuku tower. The name comes from the Roman imperial baths, and is familiar due to a hit manga series and two films. You can wander from room to room and enjoy baths with water from the Jindai no Yu hot spring, located in Izu. The baths are each named after a Roman deity, bringing the powers of these gods to play.

Depending on your preferences, you can go to the hot stone room, the sauna, the carbon baths that encourage good circulation, or you can indulge in a luxury spa treatment.

Thermae-yu Spa
1-1-2 Kabukicho
Shinjuku
160-0021 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 5285 1726

www.thermae-yu.jp/index.html

content.title: Mori Art Museum: the heights of contemporary art

introduction.small: Perched high atop a tower in the Roppongi Hills, the Mori Art Museum presents a taste of the contemporary art scene with its temporary exhibits.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mori Art Museum: the heights of contemporary art

paragraphs.text:
After having made your way through the long legs of Maman, French artist Louise Bourgeois' spider replica that presides to the building's entrance, you will go up to the 52nd floor and visit the Mori Art Museum, inaugurated in 2003.

An innovative show by the new director in 2012 called 'Arab Express' showcased emerging artists from the Middle East. Many big names in contemporary art have made their way to the museum, including the stars of Japan, the visual artist Takashi Murakami, the photographer Hiroshi Sugimoto, and the polka-dot visual artist Yayoi Kusama. International celebrities appear as well, including the video artist Bill Viola, who presented 1980s images from the Tsukiji fish market.

Be sure to take the extra ticket for the Sky Deck for a breath-taking panoramic view of Tokyo.

Mori Art Museum
Mori Tower 52F-53F
6-10-1 Roppongi
Minato
106-6153 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 5777 8600

https://www.mori.art.museum/en/index.html

content.title: Tokyo Bike: mellow peddling in Yanaka

introduction.small: Hop on a Tokyo Bike to explore the traditional neighbourhood of Yanaka.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tokyo Bike: mellow peddling in Yanaka

paragraphs.text:
The Yanaka neighbourhood is a miraculous place in Tokyo, one of the only areas to have been spared both bombings and earthquakes. Rent a 'Made in Japan' bicycle from Tokyo Bike, located in a machiya, a traditional house that has today been transformed into the hippest of bicycle stores.

Starting at the rental shop, you will go back in time by peddling along rows of traditional wooden houses, then past a typical cemetery containing no fewer than 7,000 tombs, including that of the last shogun, Tokugawa Yoshinobu. The Jomyo-in Temple shows off more than 80,000 stone statuettes in the form of Jizo, the bodhisattva of children and forgotten souls. For lunch, you can enjoy the slow-paced feel of an old coffee shop, Kayaba Coffee, dating from 1916, where you will hesitate between meat curries and egg sandwiches.

You can finish the afternoon by stopping for an artistic pause in an alternative art gallery located in an old bathhouse, hence the name Scai the Bathhouse, or by visiting the store Kamenoko Tawashi, which means 'turtle scrubbers' in Japanese, where they sell these traditional scrubbing brushes, plus t-shirts and mugs emblazoned with turtle images.

Tokyo Bike
4-2-39 Yanaka
Taito
110-0001 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 5809 0980
www.tokyobike.com

Yanaka Cemetery
7 Chome-5-24 Yanaka
Taito,
110-0001 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 3821 4456

Jomyo-in Temple
2-6-4 Ueno Sakuragi
Taito
110-0001 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 3828 2791

Kayaba Coffee
6-1-29 Yanaka
Taito

Scai The Batthouse

Kamenoko Tawashi

content.title: 21-21 Design Sight: the temple of design

introduction.small: Located in the heights of the Roppongi Hills, the 21-21 Design Sight museum features not just examples of design but its history too.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: 21-21 Design Sight: the temple of design

paragraphs.text:
Led by three mega stars of the worlds of fashion and design, Issey Miyake, the graphic artist Taku Satoh, and the industrial designer, Naoto Fukasawa, 21-21 Design Sight offers not only exhibits but also talks and workshops, all celebrating the field of design.

The museum's strange name is a reference to perfect vision, the famous 20/20. Seeing ever further and knowing the codes beyond design, such are the ambitions of this unclassifiable museum that organises major exhibitions twice a year, usually putting together the work of great artists. Note that Tadao Ando conceived of the structure of the building itself, fully integrated into the 21st century; a flat roof with steel fabric folded like origami to represent the creases of Issey Miyake's creations. When you penetrate into the heart of the building, you cannot imagine the immense finished basement.

Tadao Ando uses concrete, always his best ally and his preferred material, in a range of presentations with high, long walls and a tunnel of light. 21-21 Design Sight is worth a visit if for nothing other than the architecture itself.

21-21 Design Sight‬‬‬‬
9-7-6 Akasaka
Minato
107-0052 Tokyo‬

+81 (0)3 3475 2121

www.2121designsight.jp/en/designsight/

content.title: Ghibli Museum: Miyazaki's NTV clock and Tokyo anime

introduction.small: In the footsteps of the animation master, Hayao Miyazaki, discover another face of Tokyo, from Kichijoji to Shiodome.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ghibli Museum: Miyazaki's NTV clock and Tokyo anime

paragraphs.text:
Head to Kichijoji, a new bohemian neighbourhood in Tokyo, where designer boutiques and fashionable florists abound. From the Mitaka station take the yellow ‘cat-bus' so you can leap directly into the fantastical universe of the masterpiece, My Neighbour Totoro. Once you arrive at the Ghibli Museum, you can parade between the wolves of Princess Mononoke, laze about in the bathhouse of Spirited Away, or fly off to The Castle in the Sky.

You can relive scenes of these major animated films produced by the Ghibli Studio through film excerpts, original drawings, museum exhibits, and even a reproduction of the office of the master Miyazaki himself, where you will see the thousands of pencils he used. You can end your anime stroll at Inokashira park to take the subway.

In the Shiodome neighbourhood, at the bottom of the Nippon Television tower, Miyazaki's copper clock will entertain you, with the automatons who exit and dance about while music plays and bells chime, a real din that enchants Ghibli fans.

Ghibli Museum
1 Chome-1-83 Shimorenjaku
Mitaka
181-0013 Tokyo

+81 (0)5 7005 5777

www.ghibli-museum.jp/en/

content.title: Tokyo by night: a ramble

introduction.small: ‘Lost in Tokyo', or how to follow the mythical Scarlett Johansson through the well-lit Tokyo streets and get lost oneself until the end of the night.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tokyo by night: a ramble

paragraphs.text:
This tour will let you follow in the footsteps of Charlotte, the heroine of the film Lost in Translation, because Tokyo is indeed beautiful at night. You'll drink your first sip of Japanese whiskey at the Fireking Café, with one elbow on the gleaming bar among the jet set of Tokyo.

In the famous Karaoke Kan, ask to sing in room 601 (with the window) and relive the scene where Sofia Coppola's heroine, in her pink wig, sings a Pretenders song with Bill Murray.

Afterwards, go down to the bar of La Jetée, located at the corner of electrical Shinjuku Street, Tokyo's red-light district. Since the owner, Tomoyo, is unbeatable when it comes to cinema trivia contests, it is no coincidence that La Jetée is one of the favourite haunts of filmmakers. Finish your night in the largest electro club in Tokyo, the Womb.

Fireking Cafe
1-30-8 Uehara
Shibuya
151-0064 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3469 7911

www.fk-cafe.com

Karaoke Kan
30-8 Udagawacho
Shibuya

+81 (0)3 3462 0785

www.karaokekan.jp/index.html

La Jetée
1-1-8 Kabukicho
Shinjuku
160-0021 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3208 9645

www.lajetee.org/

Womb
‪2-16 Maruyama-cho
Shibuya
150-0044 Tokyo

www.womb.co.jp

content.title: The Palace Hotel: a neo-luxury palace

introduction.small: After a successful renovation, the Palace Hotel now shines as one of the most beautiful hotels in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Palace Hotel: a neo-luxury palace

paragraphs.text:
After being entirely renovated in 2012, what had been a worn out 1960s palace became a stunning beauty.

Allying splendour and elegance, this masterpiece is a peaceful place, marked by discrete luxury and refinement, as evidenced in the spaces and services of the hotel: the outsized lobby, the palette of earthy tones in the 290 rooms and suites, the 172-sqm exclusive lounge club on the 19th floor, the metaphorical voyage of water in the Evian spa, and the ten restaurants with various cuisines to quench any thirst and satisfy any hunger.

Paying tribute to its past and heritage, the Palace Hotel is a living example of omotenashi, Japanese hospitality.

Palace Hotel
1 Chome-1-1 Marunouchi
Chiyoda
100-0005 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3211 5211

https://en.palacehoteltokyo.com/?_ga=2.213117012.1787772181.1559810764-1083161936.1559810764

Rooms: from 55,000 JPY

content.title: Peninsula: a legend

introduction.small: This Nippon opus, in a niche near Ginza and the central train station, brings together finesse and modernism as the ideal refuge for travellers in search of Japanese refinement.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Peninsula: a legend

paragraphs.text:
Make room for luxury, calm, and exquisite pleasure. The Namibian granite walls, a two-storey entrance hall with a 1,313-light chandelier, furniture of red lacquer and leather, Kyoto wooden panels, and many art works dress up the space and make it shine. Don't miss 'The Void', a light sculpture with 24 stainless steel cones weighing 80 kilos each. At the Peninsula Academy, travellers can learn about the art and culture of the country. During visits and/or private workshops, you can discover the ins and outs of sake fabrication in a brewery, wander about the art galleries with a guide in the know, or be introduced to the arts of washi paper and kimonos. Classes on origami, cooking, or the fabrication of furin, traditional Japanese wind chimes, are also available. Arrive from the airport in Rolls Royce Phantom, for the makings of an unforgettable trip.

The Peninsula
1-8-1 Yurakucho
Chiyoda
100-0006 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 6270 2888

www.peninsula.com/en/tokyo/5-star-luxury-hotel-ginza

Rooms: from 65,000 JPY

content.title: Cerulean Tower Tokyu: the hotel at the city's epicentre

introduction.small: Playing on its height, the Cerulean Tower Tokyu lies at the very heart of the city, with a backdrop of inspiring views of Mount Fuji.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cerulean Tower Tokyu: the hotel at the city's epicentre

paragraphs.text:
Two steps from the Shibuya metro and train station, the Cerulean has an ideal geographic location.

You can witness the famous 'Shibuya Crossing', stroll through the chic neighbourhoods of Aoyama and Daikanyama and make your way down the Japanese Champs-Élysées, the Omotesando. As for the 411 rooms and suites in a contemporary style, they look out on the snows of Mount Fuji and the bright scintillating neon of Tokyo's buildings.

The 184-metre-high tower and its 37 floors shelter a spa, a fitness centre, a covered pool, and several restaurants, all with stunning views.

Cerulean Tower Tokyu
26-1 Sakuragaokacho
Shibuya
150-8512 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3476 3000

www.tokyuhotelsjapan.com/global/cerulean-h/

Rooms: from 27,400 JPY

content.title: SunnyHills: pineapple cakes galore

introduction.small: SunnyHills, an odd wooden structure, lies in the chic Omotesando neighbourhood, above the urban landscape.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: SunnyHills: pineapple cakes galore

paragraphs.text:
A few hundred metres from the Prada boutique, created by the duo of Swiss designers Herzog & de Meuron, is an oddball building covered in honeycombed wood: the SunnyHills boutique. Under its wooden carcass, dreamed up by the Japanese architect Kengo Kuma, you enter into a tearoom that only sells one dessert, a pineapple cake from Taiwan, called the SunnyHills. Your curiosity will be peaked as soon as you come close to the structure, as you discover the architectural prowess of its creator.

Wishing to recreate a giant bamboo basket, more than 5,000 metres of wood cover the surface, both inside and outside, with the traditional jigoku-gumi method, which literally means ‘an interlocking hell' and which is also seen on a smaller scale in shoji screens. This house of wooden blocks, in the heart of Tokyo, pleases passers-by and is the palace of those who love pineapple.

SunnyHills
3 Chome-10-20 Minamiaoyama
Minato
107 0062 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3408 7778

www.sunnyhills.co.jp/news.php

content.title: Book & Bed: a night in a library

introduction.small: Sleep in a library? Such is the crazy idea of this new capsule hotel in the Ikebukuro neighbourhood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Book & Bed: a night in a library

paragraphs.text:
Once upon a time, there was a hotel that told beautiful tales of sleep to its young travellers, and now what is written has been done. The architects of the Suppose Design Office agency have met the challenge and constructed an immense library with literary works of all kinds, where some bookshelves have been replaced with beds, complete with reading lights for insomniacs. You can read magazines, manga, foreign literature reviews, and comic books all night long. Books have been handpicked by Shibuya Publishing and Booksellers. Watch out: the 30 capsule beds are small, more for those out for an experience than a comfortable night in a palace. Claustrophobes stay away! In the daytime, you can wander about or do some reading in the library where different works are made available to the public.

Book & Bed
Lumière Building 7F
1­17­7 Nishi-ikebukuro
Toshima
171-0021 Tokyo

www.bookandbedtokyo.com/en/index.html

Rooms: from 3,050 JPY

content.title: Commune 246: a food truck village at Omotesando

introduction.small: In an eclectic and relaxed atmosphere, the Commune 246 project is more than a place to eat it is also a community and cultural space.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Commune 246: a food truck village at Omotesando

paragraphs.text:
Commune 246 opened in December 2014, a revival of a project with an almost identical name, 246 Common, the closing of which had saddened many. Commune 246, a micro-village in the heart of Aoyama, has work areas for ‘hot-deskers' with Internet access alongside coffee and tasty bites.

This place for hipsters also has food trucks, including the Fish Co-op, vegan dishes at Cora, and curly French fries with ginger ale at Brooklyn Ribbon Fries Komazawa there are as many inventive food offerings as there are stands to satisfy the cravings of all.

Festivals, art events, and concerts take place throughout the four seasons, breathing life into this community space, where nomadic travellers, students, designers, the fashion industry, and artists all meet up to share ideas.

Commune 246
3 Chome-13-20 Minamiaoyama
Minato
107-0062 Tokyo

commune2nd.com

content.title: Yakumo Saryo: a trip to the high point of culinary design

introduction.small: In the residential neighbourhood of Meguro, head to Yakumo Saryo, created by master Japanese designer Shinichiro Ogata from Studio Simplicity, for an extraordinary meal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Yakumo Saryo: a trip to the high point of culinary design

paragraphs.text:
Shinichiro Ogata offers a unique menu of high-flying gastronomy melding tradition and modernity. Design on the plates and pleasure in your mouth, this delicious, nirvana-inspiring cuisine leads to the famous 'wabi-sabi' experience, the quintessence of the aesthetic combination of nature and spirituality.

On the menu, ten little dishes, an exquisite kaiseki with a dessert at the end of the meal, all an artistic performance. Lunch is served in a wood-decorated room under a soft natural light with a view on the garden. You can also lunch in the kitchen, which has been converted into a dining room, where some dishes are prepared before your amused eyes. At the end of this tasty diversion, you leave with a little booklet listing the different fare on the menu.

The restaurant also includes a pastry shop, which sells Japanese sweets, and an art gallery where you can purchase sculptures made by Ogata himself. The restaurant is open to the public only for breakfast, lunch and tea. Evening meals are reserved for members or private events.

Yakumo Saryo
3-4-7 Yakumo
Meguro
152-0023 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 5731 1620

https://www.yakumosaryo.jp/e/

Menu: around 8,000 JPY

content.title: Tapas Molecular Bar: molecular cuisine with a panoramic view

introduction.small: Perched on the 38th floor of the Mandarin Oriental hotel, the Tapas Molecular Bar offers an olfactory and gustatory initiation to molecular cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Tapas Molecular Bar: molecular cuisine with a panoramic view

paragraphs.text:
At the Tapas Molecular Bar, reserve in advance for a gustatory trip to the heart of food science. Are you ready for your first taste?

Then get yourself up to the 38th floor of the Mandarin Oriental and take your place in one of just eight seats for happy travellers. For close to two hours, the artist-chefs will make your taste buds spin with stunning flavours, starting with an aperitif and followed by eleven main tapas and six desserts, all prepared before your eyes in a setting resembling a sushi bar. Each dish tells a story, sketches a theme, or retraces a transcendent taste, attempting to capture an ethereal flavour, or recreating an object suffused with nature.

The alchemy of elements, the combination of various textures, the alliance of original ingredients, all on the order of perfection. Welcome to the laboratory of the five senses!

Tapas Molecular Bar
2-1-1 Nihonbashi-Muromachi
Chuo
103-8328 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3270 8188

www.mandarinoriental.com/tokyo/fine-dining/tapas-molecular-bar/

Menu: around 18,000 JPY

content.title: A to Z Café: an artsy café with a view

introduction.small: Grant yourself a break from shopping with an exquisite lunch in an amusing place.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A to Z Café: an artsy café with a view

paragraphs.text:
Snuggled into the 5th floor of an improbable building in the Omotesando neighbourhood, not far from the Spiral Market concept store, this café with a view over the bustling city is the fruit of collaboration between the pop artist Yoshitomo Nara and the design studio Graf.

Don't hesitate to walk about this vast space with a mini-shack of wood in the centre and walls covered by the artist Nara to make an additional exhibition space. Artsy in its own way, this is a delightfully odd place. For lunch, a unique menu of the day is offered on a platter, bento style. If vertigo does not get in your way, you can lunch as a pair on the little roof terrace with a view over Aoyama.

Watch out, as the waiters do not speak English, so you will have to use your miming skills to order. But remember, smiles are universal.

A to Z Cafe
Equbo Building 5F
5-8-3 Minami-Aoyama
Minato
107-0062 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 5464 0281

www.atozcafe.exblog.jp

Menu: around 1,000 JPY

content.title: Caravan Tokyo: glamping, Nippon style

introduction.small: Rebuilt by local artisans, Caravan Tokyo is lodging like nothing else, located in the heart of the Nippon capital.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Caravan Tokyo: glamping, Nippon style

paragraphs.text:
In the centre of the city, Caravan Tokyo is an integral part of a curated project around art and street food called ‘Commune 246'. Installed in the chic neighbourhood of Omotesando, this entirely renovated vintage camping car provides all of the comfort you need, with air conditioning, a shower, bathroom, the Internet, and a breakfast table.

The mark of Japanese creativity is seen in the materials chosen, including light-coloured wood. Ingenious storage options and retractable lighting make time spent in this mini-home comfortable and enjoyable. A concierge service is offered for little escapades into town. There is space for just two people and nights are reserved on Airbnb.

Caravan Tokyo
3 Chome-13-20 Minamiaoyama
Minato
107-0062 Tokyo

www.caravantokyo.com

Rooms: from 18,000 JPY

content.title: New York Bar, Bello Visto, Two Rooms: bars with a view

introduction.small: Try one of the cocktails in the highest bars in Tokyo.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: New York Bar, Bello Visto, Two Rooms: bars with a view

paragraphs.text:
The New York Bar of the Park Hyatt, made famous by Sofia Coppola's Lost in Translation, still garners a lot of attention. While a bit outside of the centre of Shinjuku, the bar cannot be overlooked and is a must-see during a Tokyo visit. Once up there, you will be astonished by the Japanese night. The Bello Visto, on the top floor of the Cerulean Hotel, is also among the best places to drink a last glass, but also to have a good meal, as the tapas menu offers inspired Italian options. As for the Two Rooms Grill & Bar, their reputation is assured. You can have lunch on one of the most beautiful terraces in Tokyo while overlooking Aoyama. Then you will know what it is to be drunk on good fortune (but moderately of course) thanks to the views and the outstanding cocktails.

New York Bar
3-7-1-2 Nishi Shinjuku
Shinjuku
163-1055 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 5323 3458
tokyo.park.hyatt.com

Cocktails from 2,000 JPY

Bello Visto (Cerulean Hotel)

Shibuya
150-8512 Tokyo
+81 (0)3 3476 3000
www.ceruleantower-hotel.com

Cocktails from 1,700 JPY

Two Rooms Grill Bar

content.title: Hugo Desnoyers: the finest meats of France, available in Tokyo

introduction.small: In Shibuya, the artisan butcher Hugo Desnoyers installed his chopping block and counter to offer a taste of great meats.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hugo Desnoyers: the finest meats of France, available in Tokyo

paragraphs.text:
The first meat bar, 'Made in France' version, has recently arrived in Ebisu, in the Shibuya neighbourhood.

The new place, which everyone is talking about and where no one can get a reservation, has been overrun since the fall 2015 opening, and for good reason. Hugo Desnoyers holds the secret to producing the best meats of France. His project developed over many years with his trips between Japan and France as a meat expert and master butcher. With a meat shop on the first floor and a bistro on the two upper floors, the French meats are available fresh or prepared.

In the kitchen, the chef Takeshi Saita, trained by Desnoyers, offers the crème de la crème of French meats, fed and raised with care, as ensured by an ethical butcher. No reservations needed for lunch.

Hugo Desnoyers
3 Chome-4 Ebisuminami
Shibuya
150-0022 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 6303 0429

www.hugodesnoyer.com/en/content/152-restaurant-tokyo

Menu: around 2,800 JPY

content.title: Seamon Ginza: the sushi revelation

introduction.small: Three sushi chefs work in this Ginza hot spot for the best from the sea.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Seamon Ginza: the sushi revelation

paragraphs.text:
Seamon's sushi restaurant in Ginza (there is another in Nihonbashi) will be ready when you can't wait to sit down to some excellent sushi after having walked around the area and admired the architectural achievements of the Sony Building, Renzo Piano's Hermès building, and Jun Aoki's Louis Vuitton store.

You will go upstairs to a room with just 38 seats facing one long red bar to witness the creation of nigiri sushi, maki, and sashimi. Do you know that you need to be courteous, kind, and curious for one of the three chefs to serve you with care, while advising you on your meal?

Indeed, keep your eyes on the chef and a smile on your face to enter into the seduction of these culinary experts who reserve some of their creations for connoisseurs only.

Seamon Ginza
Sakaguchi Building 6F

5-5-13 Ginza
Chuo
104-0061 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 5537 0010

www.seamon.jp

Menu: around 8,000 JPY

content.title: Street food at the Tsukiji Fish Market

introduction.small: Make the most of a visit to the Tsukiji Fish Market by savouring Japanese specialties in the company of experts.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Street food at the Tsukiji Fish Market

paragraphs.text:
A true symbol of the Japanese capital, the mythical Tsukiji fish market opened its doors in 1935. Unfortunately, it was announced the government decided to close it. In autumn of 2018, it was moved to Koto, a polder located only a few miles away from its historic location.

A new adventure begins for this institution that no matter what retains its status of largest fish market in the world! For further information on Tsukiji Uogashi, as it is now named, please visit the website.

Tsukiji Uogashi
6-26-1 Tsukiji

Chuo-ku

104-0045 Tokyo

www.tsukiji.or.jp/english/

content.title: Hotel Emanon: ‘this is not a hotel'

introduction.small: Off to Shibuya, in the residential neighbourhood of Dougenzaka, where Hotel Emanon has become the reference for gastronomes of all kinds.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Emanon: ‘this is not a hotel'

paragraphs.text:
This is not a hotel, never mind its front desk, name, and upstairs rooms. No, you are not dreaming: the Hotel Emanon is a hybrid place, a 'lifestyle base' that welcomes creative communities from the city.

You can visit the restaurant on the ground floor, which offers Mediterranean dishes from a French-trained Japanese chef, wander into the 'rooms' that are now showrooms and not places to sleep, or go to the co-working spaces. Here and there you may uncover an object or piece of furniture for sale, on display in situ in one of the different areas.

For a dinner between friends, head to the table d'hôte in unfinished wood and feast your eyes on the open kitchen, then treat your taste buds. The coffee bar serves hot or cold lattes to drink here or take home. A terrace will let you make the most of good weather with a lunch in fresh air.

Hotel Emanon
7-1 Nanpeidaicho
Shibuya
150-0036 Tokyo

+81 (0)3 3780 2511

www.hotelemanon.com

Menu: around 3,000 JPY
